title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.24 Part 3 | 31-08-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Jai Vanarottamam
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, setting a spiritual tone.

segments.key_quote: In this third part, the final part, we will discuss the comparison with Maharaja Yati.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of the session, focusing on the comparison of a child's qualities to Maharaja Yati as described in Srimad Bhagavatam 1.12.24.

segments.key_quote: In his early youth he was very lustful and full of lusty desires for enjoying young girls.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to narrate the history of Maharaja Yati, focusing on his early life, his lustful desires, and his relationship with Devayani, the daughter of Shukracharya.

segments.key_quote: Sharmishta threw her, threw Devayani into a well and left her there and went away with her other friends.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the story, detailing the incident where Sharmishta throws Devayani into a well, leading to Yayati rescuing her and the subsequent conflict involving Shukracharya.

segments.key_quote: Shukracharya again became angry against Maharaja Yati and he cursed Yati to become old.
segments.summary: The story progresses with Shukracharya cursing Yati to become old due to Devayani's envy and anger over Sharmishta's pregnancy.

segments.key_quote: These material desires for enjoyment of lust are like a fire.
segments.summary: Yati exchanges his old age with his son Puru, enjoys material life, and eventually becomes disgusted, using the analogy of a goat to illustrate the insatiable nature of lust.

segments.key_quote: King Yayati, however, renounced worldly life and divided his property among his sons.
segments.summary: Yati renounces worldly life, engages in devotional service, and the speaker concludes by comparing Pariksit to Yati in terms of religiousness and charity.
